body: We can close this PR now @alexvanboxel since dhuang's got merged
@bolkedebruin looks like we still have those test issues, but I was able to run this on our production without issues
@dhuang, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @bolkedebruin and @aoen to be potential reviewers.
@amaliujia, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @artwr, @mistercrunch and @bolkedebruin to be potential reviewers.

@saguziel Im worried about your build failures on Travis. "sleep_forever" should be killed properly and it seems it isn't. The build failures I am expecting are ldap related. These are unexpected. 

Please verify and please also check your commit message against the guidelines.
Hi, @bolkedebruin any chance you can look on this PR on more time? Thanks!
@aoen @saguzie @zodiac ready for review: topological sort has been updated, tests improved. Will squash/rebase after LGTM
Is this postgres compatible?
@bolkedebruin this should fix things
@aoen @saguziel - is this still broken on Postgres?

IIRC filtering based on the DAG run was to handle an edge case. I can't recall the exact scenario, but one that I just thought up was that a DAG run and the associated tasks are created by the scheduler, but then before the tasks are able to run, the user deletes the DAG run. Arguably, then such tasks shouldn't be sent to the executor.
@plypaul  no, see https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2123
Awesome. Thanks for doing this. I'll try to hook things up and fix up a `1.7.1` branch
@jesusfcr, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @clickthisnick and @ajayyadava to be potential reviewers.
@zodiac sure, will rebase it this weekend..
@jesusfcr plz add jira id i.e. `[AIRFLOW-958]` in commit message as well..
Done!
@thesquelched, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @bolkedebruin and @saguziel to be potential reviewers.
@bolkedebruin the single test failure appears unrelated
Hey @saguziel Unfortunately, another test is now failing.
@aoen @saguziel Please review if you don't mind.
lgtm
LGTM, but please squash your commits +1
LGTM
Please add the JIRA issue to the commit message @gwax
Also add the JIRA name to the commit message @gwax
@saguziel, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @bolkedebruin and @plypaul to be potential reviewers.

I think processes are allowed to write arbitrary bytes to stdout - it might
be reasonable to pass "ignore" to decode to ignore errors since we are just
using them for the error messages

On Thursday, 9 March 2017, Scott Kruger <notifications@github.com> wrote:

> *@thesquelched* commented on this pull request.
> ------------------------------
>
> In airflow/configuration.py
> <https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2053#discussion_r105265949>
> :
>
> > @@ -76,8 +77,8 @@ def run_command(command):
>      Runs command and returns stdout
>      """
>      process = subprocess.Popen(
> -        command.split(), stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE)
> -    output, stderr = process.communicate()
> +        shlex.split(command), stdout=subprocess.PIPE, stderr=subprocess.PIPE)
> +    output, stderr = [stream.decode() for stream in process.communicate()]
>
> Argh, I forgot that the default encoding is ascii in python2. I think it
> should be reasonable to always decode as unicode, though.
>
> —
> You are receiving this because you commented.
> Reply to this email directly, view it on GitHub
> <https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2053#discussion_r105265949>,
> or mute the thread
> <https://github.com/notifications/unsubscribe-auth/AAH9OucYEvOzekwo-RBSM-FAXmbD0t1Uks5rkGP0gaJpZM4L2euY>
> .
>


-- 
Im Xuan Ji!
That seems reasonable @zodiac
LGTM after squashing
Great. Would be nice to get it on the pending 1.8 release as well!
Squashed
@sekikn, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @bolkedebruin, @mistercrunch and @alexvanboxel to be potential reviewers.
@bolkedebruin, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @jlowin and @aoen to be potential reviewers.
A single LDAP test is inexplicably failing, even though it's totally unrelated to my changes.  Maybe I need a rebase?
Tests fail on unrelated LDAP issue; should be good to merge
My [other PR](https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2135) failed on the same tests, and those changes are even more unrelated.  I think this is good to go
@bolkedebruin, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @criccomini, @NeilHanlon and @dsjl to be potential reviewers.
lgtm
lgtm, too... not that it matters ;)
@abloomston, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @jlowin and @artwr to be potential reviewers.
Note that only python 3.4 tests will pass per https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/AIRFLOW-968.
@gwax this is the minor improvement we discussed a week or so back
@dcox, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @jlowin and @bolkedebruin to be potential reviewers.

LGTM
+1
LGTM +1
@vijaykramesh You might want to rebase against master + add the JIRA name in the commit message
@saguziel, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @bolkedebruin and @patrickleotardif to be potential reviewers.
LGTM

LGTM (reviewed and iterated on this PR internally with amaliujia/saguziel), but I would get @jlowin's stamp since he is the XCOM expert.

@amaliujia I think you need to add the option explicitly to `configuration.py` so it isn't a hidden parameter. As written I believe this will crash any DAG that currently uses XComs because `enable_pickling` will be `None` and the configuration check will raise an error since the option doesn't exist. 

At a minimum, you'll need to add comments to `UPDATING.md` that make it very clear that this is a breaking change and users coming from 1.8 to 1.9 must enable pickling by default to maintain compatibility.
@aoen @bolkedebruin @gsakkis just want to touch base here -- as feared, we already have merge conflicts with new tests. If we want to commit this we will need to move rapidly.
LGTM

I still find the local import thing and the signature changes pretty hacky personally, but I won't stop others from +1ing.

If my questions re the changed signature are answered and a TODO is added to get rid of the local module imports then I guess that's good enough for now since missing test coverage is a pretty scary thing.
Please note that we were contemplating purging pickling with @mistercrunch.

I am all for increased/improved testing, but I want to see this PR being broken up. It touches several areas outside testing and this is where I feel uncomfortable. Such a large PR I am just not able to review properly.
Makes sense, but please add unit tests.
Isn't it cleaner to handle the SIGTERM in TaskInstance properly? Instead of treating it as a failure we could terminate properly and not change state. I am not entirely sure though.

@bolkedebruin I don't think we should necessarily do this. For example, for the double run protection case, I think we should fail the task. I think we define best practice as tasks being idempotent and we make the agreement to only run one task instance at a time. Consider some task A that first delete all rows in a table, then inserts 100 rows. If we don't fail the task in the case where we double run, we can end up with a situation where two instances of a task, T1 and T2, run concurrently.
T1 deletes all entries
T1 inserts 50
T2 deletes all entries
T2 inserts 100
T1 inserts 50

Then in case we have duplicate entries on 50 of the entries, which is an inconsistent state, and should not be considered a success. Unfortunately, I think we do have to special case this.
